term: Waterfall Payment: Definition, Benefits, How It Works, and Example
definition:
Investopedia / Paige McLaughlin

A waterfall payment structure sets the priority and order in which interest and principal payments are made to creditors based on rankings that can vary in some situations.

Imagine a waterfall cascading down into vertically aligned buckets. The water represents money and the buckets represent creditors. The water fills the first bucket first. The second bucket will fill only after the first is full. More buckets are filled in the order in which they appear as the water flows.

A waterfall payment structure works this way with creditors. Debtors typically structure these schemes into suchtranchesto prioritize the highest-principal loans first because they are also likely to be the most expensive.

Bucket sizes (size of debt) typically decrease as the water descends. This is likely because paying off large debts reduces the risk of insolvency and frees up cash for operations, capital expenditures, and investments.

This type of plan works best for a company repaying more than one loan. Assume this company has three operating loans, each with different interest rates. The company makes principal and interest payments on the costliest loan and makes only interest payments on the remaining two. Once the most expensive loan is paid off, the company can make all interest and principal payments on the next, more expensive loan. The process continues until allloansare repaid.

To demonstrate how a waterfall payment scheme works, assume a company has taken loans from threecreditors, Creditor A, Creditor B, and Creditor C.
